A7b: I have seen some fun examples of companies offering a ‚Äúsurprise and delight‚Äù to customers who share positive experiences. Think a free room service dessert at a hotel. It‚Äôs not promised or guaranteed; it‚Äôs intentionally spontaneous. #TwitterSmarter
#TwitterSmarter @cgritmon with the üî• GIF game!!

A7a: One of the best ways to reward customers is to acknowledge them publicly. Who doesn‚Äôt love it when a brand mentions them on Twitter? Sometimes all it takes is a simple Like or Retweet. #TwitterSmarter
@cgritmon @MadalynSklar LOL, jinx! See my last answer. #TwitterSmarter

A6c: Authentic customer commentary is far more credible than anything a CEO or Marketing department can say. People want to know ahead of time what it‚Äôs going to be like to do business with you. #TwitterSmarter

A6b: I like to say that a remarkable #customerexperience can be your best #marketing strategy. When companies do it right, their customers or clients become their best source of referrals and new business. #TwitterSmarter
@cgritmon @MadalynSklar If it's a troll, spam, or just someone spewing hateful messages, feel free to ignore/blog/delete. #TwitterSmarter
@dennis_geelen Awww, that's awesome, Dennis! üêæ #TwitterSmarter

A6a: Ratings, reviews, and customer feedback on social media are much more credible than a company talking about itself. Especially if we are creating positive experiences for our customers, we should WANT them to share. #TwitterSmarter
A5c: Answer as much as you can publicly. If there are privacy issues, direct the customer to the DM area of the same channel, such as Twitter DM. #TwitterSmarter

A5b: Answer complaints on the same channel; do not make customer switch to a different channel for your own convenience. Can you imagine if a telephone agent asked people to tweet instead? Yes countless companies ask customers who tweet to call instead. #TwitterSmarter

When I got into the marketing space at my company, it really opened my eyes to the fact that we had a blank void in terms of making intelligent decisions. https://t.co/hSQIOmU4Mj @easternbank  #customerexperience

A5a. This was actually the topic of my first book, Winning at Social Customer Care. The first step is to respond to everyone with a legitimate complaint. Show empathy and a genuine desire to solve the problem. #TwitterSmarter
@russhedge Welcome to #TwitterSmarter!
A4c: When someone takes time out of their busy day and uses their personal social capital to compliment your brand, the least you can do is respond to them and say thank you. #TwitterSmarter

A4b: Say thank you and share some love and appreciation back to the customer. #TwitterSmarter

A4a: First and foremost, you must actually respond. If I got off stage after a keynote presentation and someone said they loved my speech but I ignored them, how would they feel? Yet companies do exactly this every day in social media. #TwitterSmarter
THIS!! So simple and so often forgotten. üëá #TwitterSmarter

A3c: Understanding that customers are willing to share positive experiences than negative ones, companies must find more opportunities to deliver positivity. And let‚Äôs face it: The world needs more positivity right now. #TwitterSmarter

A3b: What we don‚Äôt want to do is overtly push for shares. ‚ÄúFollow us, share this, tag us, use our hashtag‚Äù ‚Äì too many instructions! Customers don‚Äôt want to be told what to do. #TwitterSmarter

A3a: The key is to create an experience where customers spontaneously pull out their phones and take a picture or video. This is usually accomplished by doing something unique or unexpected. #TwitterSmarter
@ChrisStrub CHRIS STRUB IS IN THE #TwitterSmarter HOUSE!! https://t.co/ergjQxL2O4

A2c: My new book, The Experience Maker, introduces a framework called WISER which contains the keys to creating experiences that people want to talk about. WISER stands for Witty, Immersive, Shareable, Extraordinary, and Responsive. #TwitterSmarter

@GiveWP @MadalynSklar ACTUALLY... data from @acquia says the opposite: People are more willing to share positive experiences than negative ones. The problem is that there aren't enough positive examples to share! But therein lies the opportunity. #TwitterSmarter

A2b: Research from @Acquia found that 30% of consumers say they would share a negative experience on social media, but nearly 50% say the same thing about a positive experience. Therein lies the opportunity for companies: create more positive customer experiences! #TwitterSmarter
@jeremy_linaburg Indeed. This is an absolute requirement today. #TwitterSmarter

A2a: Customers share the experiences at both ends of the spectrum ‚Äì very positive and very negative. What doesn‚Äôt get shared is what my millennial friends call ‚Äúmeh.‚Äù No one shares an ordinary experience. #TwitterSmarter
A1c: Social media is a channel both to collect feedback on customer experiences, and to create them. #TwitterSmarter

A1b: Social media has given customers a ‚Äúvoice‚Äù that they didn‚Äôt have in the past. When I was younger, the only way to communicate with a company was to write them a letter; today I can tweet and expect a near-instant response. #TwitterSmarter
A1a: Much of a company‚Äôs #customerexperience (good and bad) ends up shared on social media, requiring social teams to listen and respond. #TwitterSmarter

A5c: One simple trick for ensuring a cohesive experience is to ensure that every new or revised experience takes into consideration 1) where the customer was before they arrived at that part of the experience and 2) where the customer is going next. #ContentChat

A5a. Think about a brand like @Starbucks. Yes, it's about the coffee, but it's also about the atmosphere, the comfortable chairs, the smiling baristas, that SMELL of coffee beans and pastries. I know your company isn't a coffee shop but we can all learn from them. #ContentChat
A5a. "Immersive" is about being consistent across the customer journey and appealing to customers' emotions or senses. #ContentChat

A4c: All of the examples in my book have to pass through three filters, because I spent 20+ years in Corporate America so I know how hard it is to execute anything. They have to be:

1. Simple
2. Practical
3. Inexpensive

#customerexperience #ContentChat
@SFerika @Tiffani_Bova It can be, but only in certain situations. For example, the Unicorn Frappuccino at @Starbucks was an "experience" that created so much word-of-mouth marketing. #ContentChat

A4b: Look for opportunities in small places. #CustomerExperience doesn't have to be a massive, multi-year, super-expensive transformation. It can be a series of little improvements and resolving customer pain points. #ContentChat

A3c: The "W" stands for "Witty". This doesn't mean being hilarious, but rather three things:

1. Cleverness
2. Using language to your advantage
3. Refusing to be boring

#ContentChat

A3b: The good news is you don't have to use all 4 elements in WISE (in fact it's very hard to do so). But even using one will improve any #customerexperience to make it more memorable and remarkable (literally: worthy of remark). #ContentChat

A3a: The book aims to make readers "wise" to #customerexperience. WISE stands for:

Witty
Immersive
Shareable
Extraordinary

These are 4 ways to create experiences that customers want to share with others. #ContentChat
